body:
> I'm trying to match a path/filename not having some substrings in order to discard them on filters.

Can you do the inverse, so match the substrings and include them?



> Rclone is using standard golang regex lib, but it doesn't support features like lookahead assertion (?!) that will allow it.

The filters are based on file globs rather than regexps to keep them simple.

So to do this would require

- allowing regexps as filters somehow
- using the alternate regexp library

I did have an idea of another way of doing this by using a filter program which would take filenames on stdin and output them if OK or a blank line if not or something like that.

I think i saw on the source that rclone make some strings subs of the filters to convert it to regex.
May be i'm wrong.

What i'm trying is to exclude (filter -) all files that have "Sub1" or "Sub2" or "Sub3" but not have "Sub4" or "Sub5".
Examples : 
aaaaSub1bbbbb -> Excluded
aaaaSub4bbbbSub3ccc -> Not Excluded
But i cannot exlude ALL Sub1, neither include all Sub4.

> I did have an idea of another way of doing this by using a filter program which would take filenames on stdin and output them if OK or a blank line if not or something like that.

I think that will not work with mount + filters

> I think i saw on the source that rclone make some strings subs of the filters to convert it to regex.
> May be i'm wrong.

Rclone does convert the globs to regexp, but there is no way for the user to add regexps at the moment.

> > I did have an idea of another way of doing this by using a filter program which would take filenames on stdin and output them if OK or a blank line if not or something like that.
> 
> I think that will not work with mount + filters

It would work wherever filters work now.

> Rclone does convert the globs to regexp, but there is no way for the user to add regexps at the moment.

True, user cannot put regex directly.

> It would work wherever filters work now.

Yes, now works, you can use filters with mount. 
I mean that you cannot get that filelist to filter from a remote without a great impact. Having to get the list from the remote.
And this list won't be dinamic, i mean, is a static list and you will have to umount, get the list and mount again. With the filter it's dinamic, you can up files to the remote and the it will appear, or not, on the filter mount if it match with the filter rules.

> So to do this would require
>  - allowing regexps as filters somehow
>  - using the alternate regexp library

For the first point i think that you can use the first character to set the lib to use :  
+- : Include/Exclude "Globs" String
*/  : Include/Exclude "Re2" String

It will be backguards compatible.
Something still needed here or can this be closed out?

I will love to see this implemented in rclone, and i think it will be usefull for anyone, but it's not on my hands to implement it.

If there's any chance to be implemented in the future i wouldn't close.
But if there's no chance to get it you can close it.
All good. I can tag it as an enhancement and leave it open.

rename.from: Enhance Filters : for example Match excluding substrings
rename.to: Enhance Filters : allow regexp matches to for example Match excluding substrings

issue.title: rclone filters to support regex

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### The associated forum post URL from `https://forum.rclone.org`
https://forum.rclone.org/t/full-support-for-regex-for-filters/26883

#### What is your current rclone version (output from `rclone version`)?
```
rclone v1.56.0
- os/version: Microsoft Windows 10 Pro 2009 (64 bit)
- os/kernel: 10.0.19043.1266 (x86_64)
- os/type: windows
- os/arch: amd64
- go/version: go1.16.5
- go/linking: dynamic
- go/tags: cmount
```

#### What problem are you are trying to solve?
that rclone should fully support regex for filters
currently, rclone partially supports regex

this works
```
rclone ls D:\files\reg --include={\d\d\d\d\d\d\d\d} --dump=filters 
2021/10/07 17:41:21 NOTICE: Automatically setting -vv as --dump is enabled
--- start filters ---
--- File filter rules ---
+ (^|/)(\d\d\d\d\d\d\d\d)$
- ^.*$
--- Directory filter rules ---
+ ^.*$
- ^.*$
--- end filters ---
2021/10/07 17:41:21 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.56.0" starting with parameters ["c:\\data\\rclone\\scripts\\rclone.exe" "ls" "D:\\files\\reg" "--include={\\d\\d\\d\\d\\d\\d\\d\\d}" "--dump=filters"]
2021/10/07 17:41:21 DEBUG : Creating backend with remote "D:\\files\\reg"
2021/10/07 17:41:21 DEBUG : Using config file from "C:\\data\\rclone\\scripts\\rclone.conf"
2021/10/07 17:41:21 DEBUG : fs cache: renaming cache item "D:\\files\\reg" to be canonical "//?/D:/files/reg"
        0 20210101
        0 20210102
        0 20210103
2021/10/07 17:41:21 DEBUG : 2 go routines active

```

but this does not work
```
rclone ls D:\files\reg --include=*.{\d{8}}  --dump=filters 
2021/10/07 17:37:47 NOTICE: Automatically setting -vv as --dump is enabled
2021/10/07 17:37:47 Failed to load filters: can't nest '{' '}' in glob "*.{\\d{8}}"
```

#### How do you think rclone should be changed to solve that?
please allow for full regex functionality. thanks

body:
There are two options for adding regexp syntax to rclone filters.

1. Find something which is currently illegal in the glob syntax and use that to mean regexp. Probably the most promising would be to wrap regexps in `{{}}` this would mean that then could be part of globs also. A Real glob supports nested `{}` though (which rclone's doesn't due to laziness on my part). Other alternatives would be to start a regexp with `]` or `}` or `***`
2. Extend the `--filter` syntax to have a different prefix to indicate a regexp `--filter "-r regexp"`  or `--filter "+r regexp"`

Thoughts?

rename.from: Enhance Filters : allow regexp matches to for example Match excluding substrings

body:
in addition of `--filter`, would be nice to include `--include` and not exclude `--exclude`

imho,
item 1 - filters are complex enough , so adding `{{}}` would confuse the less technical rcloners.
item 2 - would preserve the current syntax and extend it for regex.

in the docs, perhaps add a link to a website such as 

"A Go regular expression tester"
https://regoio.herokuapp.com/

thanks

@asdffdsazqqq `--filter` is the only flag which takes a prefix which can be (ab)used to mean this is a regexp. So that is the only option for option 2. Point taken about `{{}}` it is going to start looking quite complex! We could of course do both...
... Or even https://filterdemo.rclone.org/ which I made a while back - needs a bit more work but might be useful...

well, regex is already an advanced syntax and anybody using that will not have an issue with `{{}}`
just curious about `.*\d{8}`; would the rclonerized version be `{{.*\d{8}}}`

fwiw, i would prefer pure regex syntax and copy/paste from https://regoio.herokuapp.com/

what about `--rinclude=.*\d{8}`, `--rexclude=.*\d{8}` and so on?

I don't use filters a lot but in my opinion, we should probably add the r-prefixed flags (rfilter, rinclude, rexclude) as mentioned by @asdffdsazqqq. That way we preserve the backwards compatibility without adding any unnecessary complexity. Perhaps, in rclone 2.0 (TBD :wink:), we could consider consolidating those.

> well, regex is already an advanced syntax and anybody using that will not have an issue with `{{}}` just curious about `.*\d{8}`; would the rclonerized version be `{{.*\d{8}}}`

That's right.

> fwiw, i would prefer pure regex syntax and copy/paste from https://regoio.herokuapp.com/
> 
> what about `--rinclude=.*\d{8}`, `--rexclude=.*\d{8}` and so on?

Hmm, that would need another 6 flags `--rinclude`, `--rinclude-from`, `--rexclude`, `--rexclude-from`, `--rfilter`, `--rfilter-from` - we could do that, it just seems a bit messy! Then again we already have 144 global flags (not counting backend flags) so what is a few more! I'd probably be slightly more explicit on the flag names `--re-include`, `--re-include-from`, `--re-exclude`, `--re-exclude-from`, `--re-filter`, `--re-filter-from`. Let's call that option 3. You'd also have the problem that mixing `re` and non-`re` flags would do weird things in the same way that mixing `--include` and `--exclude` does now.

I'm probably leaning towards the `{{regexp}}` option as it would be easy to implement (probably only half a dozen lines of code + some tests), could be mixed with the glob syntax so `*.{{[txt]{3}}}` and doesn't require a whole suite of new flags.

> I don't use filters a lot but in my opinion, we should probably add the r-prefixed flags (rfilter, rinclude, rexclude) as mentioned by @asdffdsazqqq. That way we preserve the backwards compatibility without adding any unnecessary complexity. Perhaps, in rclone 2.0 (TBD wink), we could consider consolidating those.

Note that using `{{regexp}}` is backwards compatible, because currently that is a syntax error in the glob syntax.
